description: From French alouatte, alouate, from a Cariban language; compare Galibi Carib arawata, Trió arawata, Wayana alawata, Maquiritari adawa'ta, Apalaí arauta, Akawaio arawta, Pemon arauta, Macushi arauta. Compare araguato.

entries.meaning: (now rare) A South American howler monkey (of the genus Alouatta). [from 18th c.]
examples: I understood what he meant, and said, ‘Alouattes are shot every day.’
